title: The Sound That Stays: Bone Flute and the Poetry of Enduring Voice
description: What makes Bone Flute especially powerful is the way it invites readers in.
content:
Some books do not need to shout to be heard. They speak quietly and clearly, with a kind of wisdom that lingers. Bone Flute: A Woman Speaks is one of those rare collections that opens a space for readers to breathe, observe, and remember what matters. It is not interested in spectacle. Instead, it pays attention to small joys, fleeting thoughts, family bonds, the rhythm of days. And in that attention, it finds something close to magic.

This poetry collection was not written for a spotlight. It grew over time, poem by poem, across twenty-five years of reflection and daily writing. The result is a body of work that feels deeply lived-in. The voice that emerges is clear, curious, wry, and endlessly generous.

What makes Bone Flute especially powerful is the way it invites readers in. These poems speak plainly but precisely, with images that feel both familiar and unexpectedly tender. Whether describing a memory, a moment in the garden, or a scrap of conversation, the poems create the feeling of sitting across from someone who knows how to listen.

The Shape of the Book

Irene Adler spent more than two decades writing over two thousand poems: quiet, deliberate reflections gathered from her daily life. She didn’t write for acclaim. She wrote because it grounded her. After years of exchanging drafts and sharing poems with close friend and poet Angela Narciso Torres, Adler’s body of work took on new form.

Following Irene’s vision, Torres, together with poets Gail Goepfert, Naoko Fujimoto, and Timothy Torres, shaped a manuscript that honored the emotional range and subtlety of her writing. The result is a collection that moves with grace between wonder and restraint, clarity and curiosity, always in Adler’s unmistakable voice.

The book is structured like a quiet conversation. Nan Cohen, who wrote the foreword, describes the poems as “traveling through the seasons of her life,” but more than that, they feel like steady footfalls on a familiar path. One poem may recall a kitchen moment with a loved one; the next may hold a small observation about birdsong or the feel of the morning light. The tone is calm, but never distant.

There is also delight in the ordinary. Adler’s poems are filled with the texture of daily life, meals, gardens, handwritten notes, glances exchanged. Her humor comes in flashes, never loud but always welcome. Poet Robin Ekiss calls the work “pragmatic, patient, and wily.” These acknowledge how much life is packed into a few short lines.

Rather than searching for drama, Bone Flute leans into the quiet marvels of everyday experience. The natural world makes frequent appearances: owls, beetles, birds, and blossoms populate the pages, not as metaphors, but as companions in observation. The poems do not press meaning onto these creatures. They simply notice and in that noticing, something opens.

There is a poem about tulips that captures this perfectly. Their presence becomes a brief, joyous interruption. The kind of thing you might smile at on a walk, then remember days later without knowing why. This is how Adler’s poems work: they plant themselves gently and grow in your thoughts.

Relationships play a central role throughout the collection. There are quiet portraits of sisterhood, family ties, long marriages, enduring friendships. Adler writes about her loved ones with honesty and kindness. Her poems share a remembered conversation, a habit passed down, a joke between siblings, all become material for reflection and quiet celebration.

The poems also have a gentle pace, an awareness of time that comes from years of paying attention. There is joy in routine, in the cycles of planting and harvesting, in the rhythm of writing each day. This is not nostalgia, rather the kind of clarity that arrives when someone has learned to live deeply in their own life.

The Woman Behind the Voice

Irene Adler, the woman behind Bone Flute, didn’t begin publishing poetry in her early years. For fifteen years, she taught English, and for many more, she was a wife, mother, friend, and observer of the world. She began writing poems seriously later in life, as a personal commitment, a daily practice to stay connected to language, emotion, and reflection. Over time, this practice filled notebooks and folders with poems that captured decades of thought and feeling.

Her husband, Alan Adler, supported the project from the beginning. Their marriage lasted sixty-one years, and it is clear that his encouragement was part of the soil from which the poems grew. After her passing, he helped bring the book to life, donating all proceeds to Stanford Medicine’s cancer research and endowing a chair in her name. The book is part tribute, part living document of the life they shared and the ideas she cared about.

The editorial team, many of whom had shared poems with Adler over the years, speak of her with affection and admiration. She wasn’t writing for fame. She wrote to be present. Her voice was not crafted for the page, it was lived into the page. That is why the collection feels so natural and intimate.

Bone Flute invites people to slow down. To listen, to notice, and in doing so, it offers something rare: a feeling of connection that doesn’t demand anything in return.

The title itself is perfectly chosen. A bone flute is one of the oldest instruments known to humankind. It is simple, hand-carved, made to carry sound softly across time. Adler’s poetry carries that same spirit: crafted with care, made from what life offered, and resonant in a way that does not fade.

This is a book that rewards returning, the kind of book you leave on a nightstand, revisit in a quiet moment, share with someone you care about. There’s comfort in these poems. Not because they are sweet or safe, but because they tell the truth gently. They are a reminder that attention is a kind of love.
summary: Irene Adler has published over two decades of poetry, with The Sound That Stays: Bone Flute: A Woman Speaks, a collection that invites readers to breathe, observe, and remember what matters. The book was compiled by close friend and poet Angela Narciso Torres and includes five other poets including Gail Goepfert, Naoko Fujimoto, and Timothy Torres. The poems are described as clear, curious, wry, and endlessly generous. They are structured like a quiet conversation, with images that feel familiar and tender. The natural world makes frequent appearances, with the natural world being seen as companions in observation. The collection was published after Adler's husband, Alan Adler, supported the project from the beginning of their marriage.

Bone Flute: A Woman Speaks
IRENE ADLER
Poetry
Edited by Angela Narciso Torres
“It’s been my great honor and privilege to serve as the courier for Irene’s windblown letter to the world. I can think of no higher tribute to a fellow sojourner in poetry and in life. I am certain that, like the bone flute, these poems will continue to sing throughout the ages.”
—Angela Narciso Torres, author of What Happens Is Neither

Press Release
Book Release Posthumously Honors the Legacy of Los Altos Poet and Philanthropist Irene Adler
San Mateo, Ca., 29 April 2025 — In a tribute to the enduring power of poetry, Paloma Press is pleased to announce the posthumous release of Bone Flute: A Woman Speaks, a collection of lyrical poems by Irene Adler. Edited by award-winning poet Angela Narciso Torres, Bone Flute provides a longitudinal poetic record of American life and womanhood echoing Linda Pastan, Mona Van Duyn, and Grace Paley.
“After a career of teaching English for about 15 years, Irene began writing every day. I loved it and was her devoted cheerleader. She often wrote about something she encountered in her life,” recalls Alan Adler, Irene’s husband of 61 years and inventor of the Aerobie flying ring and the Aeropress coffee maker. Irene was also a philanthropist and contributed substantial funds to support cancer research at Stanford University. After Irene passed away in October 2023, Alan endowed a chair at Stanford Medicine in her name. In addition to making a difference in the lives of countless cancer patients, Irene left behind over 2,000 unpublished poems written over 25 years. “Now that we have Bone Flute,” Alan continues, “I’m eager to expose the world to Irene’s wonderful poetry. Royalties will go to the Cancer Research at Stanford University as Irene wished. I intend to do all that can be done to share this book with the world.”
Many hands helped bring Bone Flute to life. Angela Narciso Torres, Irene’s friend of more than 20 years, formed an editorial committee made up of fellow poets Gail Goepfert, Naoko Fujimoto, and Timothy Torres. The book features a Foreword by Nan Cohen, and advance words by Sally Ashton, Robin Ekiss, Peter Kline, and Cintia Santana, all of whom knew Irene. The family and friends of Irene Adler, in association with Paloma Press, are organizing readings to celebrate the book’s release. Bone Flute: A Woman Speaks is available April 29, 2025 through leading online retailers and booksellers. Coverage of the book has appeared in the Redwood City Pulse, The Almanac, Mountain View Voice, Palo Alto Weekly, and Los Altos Crier.
Synopsis
Inspired by Bishop and Dickinson, Bone Flute: A Woman Speaks by Irene Adler gives equal voice to the unspeakable sorrows and wonders of being alive. Edited by award-winning poet Angela Narciso Torres, this posthumous collection provides a longitudinal poetic record of American life and womanhood echoing Linda Pastan, Mona Van Duyn, and Grace Paley.
Praise
“Reading Bone Flute, we travel with the poet through the seasons of her life, moving through history, through memory, through geography, and yet with a powerful sense of immediacy. I feel certain that there are poems here . . . that will survive the way poems do, lodged like a tough plant in a crack in someone’s heart.”
—from the foreword by Nan Cohen, author of Unfinished City
“’We leave things at a wild velocity,’ poet Irene Adler writes in Bone Flute, her moving, posthumous collection. In poems that demonstrate an equal tenderness toward life and loss, Adler celebrates the small but profound joys that make any life a miracle in spite of suffering, ‘black clouds fringed silver.’ Here, love and sorrow walk hand in hand. Such poems are like a bone flute, one that plays ‘notes that made a bleak night shine,’ notes that continue to echo and shimmer in our memory and in the poems found here. Adler plays a fine, sweet music you won’t want to miss.”
—Sally Ashton, author of Listening to Mars
“Irene Adler’s poems are pragmatic, patient, and wily, defiant in their desire for forgiveness and forbearance. With a stark, self-reflexive beauty both airy and earth-bound, Irene’s small and sacred meditations reveal what the owls, birds, and beetles already know: life’s ‘wild velocity’ lives in every ‘quill, bone, and feather.’ As a sister, daughter, and mother, these poems that ‘sing with delight/for secret reasons’ will live in me for a long time.”
—Robin Ekiss, author of The Mansion of Happiness
“In this passionate, moving collection, Irene Adler distills a lifetime of asking the big questions into slender lyrics shimmering with longing, grief, and awe. With a delicate sense of music, these poems explore themes of romantic love, familial bonds and trauma, childhood and coming of age, the natural world, and intimations of the divine. In ‘Genesis,’ after laying out an alternate cosmology, Adler writes in a line both wry and uncanny, ‘In the beginning, even God was green.’ Cleaning voracious pests from her grandmother’s garden, her speaker sees not devastation but a vision of ecstasy: ‘We might all be drowning in roses.’ The deepest subject of the book is mortality, both that of the speaker and of those she loves, a subject she treats with unsentimental bravery, as in this terse advice from ‘Heading Home’: ‘leave this life more lightly than / you came and make swift goodbyes.’ Bone Flute is a wise testament to the pain and wonder of being human.”
—Peter Kline, author of Mirrorforms
“Bone Flute is a testament to the elegance of the word. Smooth-seeming are the waters into which Irene Adler’s words cleanly dive. Through an ease with music and form—from tankas to sonnets—Adler brings a pianist’s sensibilities to the page. Her unswerving observations of our human plight surface and surprise again and again: from the humorous (‘Above the poet’s voice a cry of geese / in flight adds honking to her sonnet.’) to the marvelous, through which grief and human desire (‘we covet in colors.’) entwine and complicate.”
—Cintia Santana, author of The Disordered Alphabet

About the Author
Irene Adler was a poet and English teacher in Palo Alto, California where she was also a co-owner of the company that invented the Aerobie flying ring and the Aeropress coffee maker. By the time of her death in October 2023, she had written over 2,000 poems spanning 25 years.
